folder: Harlem River Drive & Dyckman Street, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: Harlem River Drive - Dyckman Street
text:
Harlem River Speedway, at the northern point where it bends westward to become Dyckman Street. This view taken during the bicycle days illustrates the mode of dress of that date.
About 1897.

Ewing Galloway.

folder: Dyckman Street & Fort George Avenue, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: Dyckman Street - Fort George Avenue
text:
Dyckman Street, west of Fort George Ave. This section is also known as being a portion of the Harlem River Speedway. Shown on the right, is Sherman Creek.
October 26, 1927.

F.L. Sperr

Dyckman Street, west from Tenth Ave., showing (left) a portion of Highbridge Park and (background) the Seventh Ave.-Van Cortlandt Park Line of the I.R.T. subway running at this point on an elevated structure on Nagle Ave.

April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Dyckman Street, south side, east from but not including Tenth Ave., showing a portion of Highbridge Park. From the point where the street makes a sharp bend southward (left) is the Harlem River Driveway running along the western shore of the Harlem River. In the distant background is visible the University Heights section of the Bronx.
April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Harlem River Drive & Dyckman Street, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: Harlem River Drive - Dyckman Street
text:
(1)
Harlem River Driveway, east side, slightly south of Dyckman Street (where it commences), showing the entrance and narrow approach to the Manhattan Patrol Life Saving Service, at the Harlem River. Across the river (background) appears the New York University Buildings, which are in the Bronx.

P. L. Sperr.

April 20, 1937.

(2)
A detail of the same, (not seen in view 1), showing the boat house of the Manhattan Patrol Life Saving Service on the river. (This boat house is obstructed from sight in view 1, by the passageway and a wooden shed).

April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Harlem River Drive & Dyckman Street, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: Harlem River Drive - Dyckman Street
text:
Harlem River Driveway, east side, slightly south of Dyckman Street (where it commences), showing the entrance to the Lone Star Boat Club on the Harlem River. In the background is discernible the west shore of the borough of the Bronx.

April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
